awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate and teacher research in physics at Northern Illinois University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site at the Department of Physics of Northern Illinois University (NIU). Research topics will focus on particle physics, beams and accelerator physics, and condensed matter physics.  Students will work on cutting-edge research and will receive lectures on numerous topics, including how to get started on their research, the usefulness of a degree in physics, the long path towards attending graduate school, and other options for fruitful careers after graduation. The program will take advantage of the proximity of the NIU to nearby national labs, with several students working a few days a week at Fermilab, and all students taking tours and trips to visit both Fermilab as well as Argonne. Building on NIU's strong physics and science teacher certification program, the RET component will allow local teachers to experience real physics research and participate in lectures and programs that aim to disrupt and disperse the roadblocks that women and minorities face in the pipeline towards careers in STEM fields.

The research topics for this proposal fall into three broad categories: 1) particle physics,2) accelerator and beams physics, and 3) materials and condensed matter physics. The particle and beams and accelerator physics research topics for this proposal will be based in NIU's Northern Illinois Center for Accelerator and Detector Development (NICADD), which hosts the University's accelerator, detector and particle physics research programs.  Students will be housed on campus, and their work will be based primarily at the department, though some participants working in beams physics or particle physics may work a few days a week at Fermilab, depending on their research topics.  Teachers in the program, who are more likely to have their own transportation and families to attend to, will have the option of working on campus or at Fermilab.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NIU REU/RET program provided opportunities for student and K-12 researchers to perform cutting-edge physics research in a group setting while accessing lectures and instructional material about modern physics and how to apply to graduate school. The K-12 teachers then brought their research experiences back to their science classrooms. Students in the program were selected from a variety of backgrounds, but with a specific emphasis and focus on local community colleges. Students in this group often do not have access to physics research opportunities, and the program aimed to show them how interesting and unique research can be, and also to provide a mentoring and support structure for students to succeed. In total, 21 students and 4 teachers participated in the program over the 3 years of the project. The connection between teachers and students was an important part of the program, as they learned from one another and also provided each other with different viewpoints. 

Outside of the pandemic, participants also took tours of the local FNAL and ANL facilities and participated in local NIU campus events. Research opportunities spanned a wide range of topics across particle physics, accelerator and beams physics, biophysics and condensed matter physics. Specific projects included hardware and experimental research, simulation studies and theoretical work. 

Both the end-of-summer and follow-up surveys found that the participants were overwhelmingly positive about their participation in the program. The vast majority of participants reported that they enjoyed the experience, learned a lot about doing research, were better prepared for advanced courses/graudate school/employment, and were more likely to pursue a graduate degree in a STEM field. Follow-up surveys one year after their participation, while having a lower response rate, showed that participants were still very positive about the experience. Of those REU participants who completed the one-year follow-up survey, all were either continuing their undergraduate studies, or enrolled in a graduate program. An attempt was made at follow-up surveys two years (and more) past program completion, but due to challenges in contacting students (likely from changing emails due to changing institutions), reponse rates were very low. Informal contacts with previous participants indicates that at least two are currently pursuing graduate degrees in STEM.
